body:
create a script for parsing the output from `bitcoind --help` to create an example conf file for new users. this PR is ready to merge when:

- [x] create script (proof of concept)
- [ ] lint script to fix ci failures
- [ ] ensure script is portable across different operating systems

## problem

per #10746 , `bitcoin.conf` not being put into the data directory during installation causes some confusion for users when running bitcoin. more details in the issue

## solution

since its non-trivial to generate and put it directly into the data directory during install, a simpler proposal was to create an example `bitcoin.conf` file in `share/examples` and instruct users to copy it to their data directory if would like to customize the options via the config file. however, since the command line and `bitcoin.conf` file are meant to be one to one, it's not ideal to have two sources of truth on what options are available. instead, we can use the option help from `bitcoind` as the source of truth and generating the file from that using a script. this was suggested in #10746 

this is an attempt to do that by running a shell script during `make install` which parses the output of `bitcoind --help` into `share/examples/bitcoin.conf`

it is then up to the user to edit the file and copy it into their data directory (dependent on their operating system).

## special considerations

this does re-write the current `share/examples/bitcoin.conf` which seemed to have extra info about the parameters. rather than keeping both files, i suggest having the one auto-generated file and any documentation about using options should be moved into `init.cpp`

i also edited `init.cpp` to have the option help indicate that `-conf` is not usable from the config file. this is similar to how `-includeconf` 's help indicates it cannot be used from the command line
title: script: add script to generate example bitcoin.conf
